perturbation.original_text: Neither the Franchisor, its Predecessor nor any person listed under Item 2 or an affiliate offering franchises under Franchisor's principal trademark:     (A) has an administrative, criminal or civil action pending against that person alleging: a felony; a violation of a franchise, antitrust or securities law; fraud; embezzlement; fraudulent conversion; misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive practices; or comparable civil or misdemeanor allegations.
perturbation.changed_text: Neither the Franchisor, its Predecessor nor any person listed under Item 2 or an affiliate offering franchises under Franchisor's principal trademark:     (A) has an administrative, criminal or civil action pending against that person alleging: a felony; a violation of a franchise, antitrust or securities law; fraud; embezzlement; fraudulent conversion; misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive practices; or comparable civil or misdemeanor allegations, unless such action is deemed by the Franchisor's legal counsel, in their sole discretion, to be without merit.
perturbation.explanation: This change adds an exception to the condition where actions are pending. The original text indicates a strict prohibition against pending actions of certain types. The modified text introduces an exception if the Franchisor's legal counsel deems the action without merit. This creates a contradiction because, in another section, any pending action may trigger certain liabilities, but this clause gives the Franchisor discretion to ignore them, leading to uncertainty and potential disputes.

perturbation.original_text: Neither the Franchisor, its affiliate, its predecessor, officers, or general partner during the ten year period immediately before the date of the disclosure document: (a) filed as debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code (or any comparable foreign law); (b) obtained a discharge of its debts under the bankruptcy code; or (c) was a principal officer of a company or a general partner in a partnership that either filed as a debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or that obtained a discharge of its debts under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code during or within one year after the officer or general partner of the Franchisor held this position in the company or partnership.
perturbation.changed_text: Neither the Franchisor, its affiliate, its predecessor, officers, or general partner during the ten year period immediately before the date of the disclosure document: (a) filed as debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code (or any comparable foreign law); (b) obtained a discharge of its debts under the bankruptcy code; or (c) was a principal officer of a company or a general partner in a partnership that either filed as a debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or that obtained a discharge of its debts under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code during or within one year after the officer or general partner of the Franchisor held this position in the company or partnership, provided however that such events shall not be considered a disqualifying factor if the Franchisor can demonstrate that the circumstances leading to the bankruptcy were beyond the control of the individual or entity.
perturbation.explanation: This change adds a proviso to the bankruptcy clause. The original text establishes a strict ten-year look-back period for bankruptcy events. The modified text introduces an exception if the Franchisor can prove the circumstances were beyond their control. This creates ambiguity because in other sections, the occurrence of a bankruptcy event automatically triggers certain penalties or termination rights, but this modification potentially allows the Franchisor to avoid those consequences by demonstrating circumstances beyond their control. What constitutes 'beyond the control' is not defined, creating room for interpretation and disputes.
